coldOpen.text:
You are Yousaff.

Edmonton. Law school. Too many tabs open.

One tab: “ATB 101 — Tell us your story, your way.”
Another tab: a message from a community group:
“Can you help us explain a legal issue in plain language… tonight?”

Your brain does the thing it always does:
How do I make something useful, and ship it on time?

What do you do first?

choices.label: Help the community request first, then build the application around what I did
Start the application first (I’ll help after)

impactMoment.text:
You jump in.

This is familiar: public-facing legal education.
You’ve done sessions for diverse groups and learned fast that clarity is a form of respect.

The group asks: “Can we get a one-page explanation someone can actually understand?”

How do you respond?

choices.label: Write a one-pager in plain language + a short script they can read out loud
Write a classic legal memo (thorough, careful, a bit dense)

impactDelivered.text:
They reply: “This is exactly what we needed.”

Now the second mission:
ATB asked for “Your Story, Your Way.”
Not a standard cover letter.
Something vivid.

You choose a format that matches who you are: building things.
What do you build?

choices.label: A choose-your-own-adventure game that lets your choices prove your values
A safe video intro (clean, standard, low-risk)

gameDevRoute.text:
You build the CYOA.

This also feels familiar: you’ve shipped games, built online platforms, and learned that ‘fun’ only counts if the experience is clear.

New problem:
The game is about you. But trust is built with other people.

Who do you involve?

choices.label: Ask people to playtest and tell you what’s confusing (then actually iterate)
Keep it solo so it’s purely ‘my’ work

playtest.text:
Your playtester says:

“Fun. But I still don’t know what you’re like on a team.
ATB wants someone who can stand up, speak out, and still bring people with them.”

You can get defensive… or you can improve the product.

What do you do?

choices.label: Add a scene where you respectfully challenge a plan and offer a better one
Ignore it — the game is already good

speakOut.text:
New scene:

A team meeting is drifting toward a ‘safe’ decision.
It won’t actually solve the client problem.

You speak up:
“I think we’re missing a simpler option. Can I propose another path?”

How do you follow through?

choices.label: Offer a concrete alternative, tradeoffs, and a fast next step the team can agree on
Point out the problem and stop there

getThingsDone.text:
That’s the pattern in your life:

- advocacy when it matters
- systems when they help
- clarity when people need it

You remember the City role: defending positions in a tribunal setting, and improving outcomes by building better processes.

Final build decision: how do you make the game feel ‘ATB-ready’?

choices.label: Add a scoreboard (Impact / Thrive / Ready) so the mechanics reflect the values
Keep it minimal (choices + endings only)

shipEnding.text:
You ship it on GitHub Pages.

A recruiter plays for 90 seconds.
They don’t just read claims.
They see evidence:

Impact in action.
Thrive together.
Ready for tomorrow.

ENDING: Your Story, Your Way — shipped.

cleanEnding.text:
You ship a clean version.
It’s readable and professional.

But the scoreboard layer would’ve made the values feel built-in, not stated.

ENDING: Clean win.

pressureMoment.text:
You start the application first.
It looks polished.
But something feels off.

You know you’re at your best when you’re doing real work that helps someone.

What do you do?

choices.label: Switch: help the community request now, then tell the story honestly
Push through and submit something generic

genericEnding.text:
You submit something fine.

But it doesn’t feel like you.

ENDING: Polished, but not memorable.

denseMemo.text:
The memo is thorough.
But the group replies:

“We can’t use this directly. It’s too dense for the person we’re trying to help.”

You get a second chance.
What do you do?

choices.label: Translate it into plain language and own the miss
Defend the memo: “This is how legal work is.”

stuckEnding.text:
You’re not wrong about complexity.
But you missed the point: serving people.

ENDING: Technically correct, practically ineffective.

safeRoute.text:
You make a video intro.
It’s professional.

But you know you’ve built more interesting things than this.
And ATB literally asked for something non-traditional.

Do you pivot?

choices.label: Pivot to the CYOA and keep the video as an optional extra
Ship the video as-is

safeEnding.text:
It’s solid.
But it doesn’t scream ‘innovative, digital, entrepreneurial.’

ENDING: Safe, but not distinctive.

solo.text:
You keep it solo.
You love it.

A friend plays and says:
“I got lost. I’m not sure what you want me to learn about you.”

What now?

choices.label: Bring in playtesters and iterate (collaboration is part of the product)
Leave it as a ‘smart person will get it’ thing

ignoreFeedbackEnding.text:
It’s fun.
But you missed a chance to show growth and collaboration.

ENDING: Fun, slightly closed-off.

almostEnding.text:
You raised the issue.
Everyone nods.
Then they keep the same plan.

Lesson: speaking up is great. Speaking up with a path forward is better.

ENDING: Almost.

confusingEnding.text:
Clever, but unclear.

ENDING: The player quits before the good part.
